answers.answer: Everyone's cataract progresses at different rates. You should have cataract surgery when it interferes with your daily function.Dr. O.
Thank you for your reply.  I am seeing my doctor next week.

Hello, the pace of progression of cataract varies from person to person. Progression of cataract is also affected by a number of factors like exposure to UV rays, diabetes, use of medicines like steroids, vitamin deficiencies, and conditions like glaucoma, eye injuries etc. Hence, the only advice that can be given is to have your cataract removed when it begins to affect your daily activities. Good luck with your vision!

question: I am a 54 female - I had a childhhod cataract develop in my right eye at age 6, then glaucoma in that eye at age 13.  Surgery back then was a big deal for cataracts, so I never had it done.  I did have successful glaucome surgery which has kept my eye pressure down - until about two years ago, when I went on Xalantan for it.  It has kept the pressure under control. I have had no vision in my right eye since my late teens.Recently, I have developed a cataract in my left eye.  My left eye has been very healthy with no problems, although I do have significant floaters in that eye.  My retina is checked regularly and the interior of that eye looks good. But, last fall I had significant blurriness, so went in and my prescription changed a bit - due to the cataract. Now, my vision has again become blurry which is likely due to the cataract.  I know I need a new prescription.  When should I have cataract surgery - and how fast do cataracts typically progress?  I am alarmed I have blurry vision again so soon after the last correction, which was my first in about 4 years.  Thank you for your input.
title: When should I have cataract surgery?
